text: my associates and I spent months really
looking at the history of New Orleans
and Saint Dominique and really beginning
to analyze and understand the political
situation of what was happening
historically in that part of the world
because clothing in essence always comes
out of power and political situations so
the understanding of that was the very
first step even before we could begin
the visual research for the project
looking at the design of the women for
free men of color Josephine was truly
the major fashion influence that was
happening at the time and actually this
kind of fit in such an amazing way into
New Orleans there is it in the 1790s we
have a silhouette that is not quite on
here its high waisted but it's not quite
on pier and it is much like what we find
in the Goya portraiture so it has a more
Spanish influence and then we go into
the zenith of Napoleon and Josephine and
the arm Pierre silhouette so that became
really the basis of of what the design
is going to be for any of the woman's
silhouette wise and then you really run
into in a very basic way fashion comes
off of political situations and the
power if they're there for the wealth of
countries and our show indeed becomes
about a man Jacques corneille who indeed
was fashion is he is what his whole life
is lived for and the idea of being able
to get those fabrics from around the
world as quickly as possible to him in
New Orleans is what it all stems from
and Don guerre has from that point of
view indeed told us a story about power
and political situations and wealth all
based on fashion
